;Recently, milk tea in Xinjiang has become a hot topic.

;

;Some netizens posted pictures showing that when buying milk tea in Xinjiang, a cup starts at 1kg, triggering heated discussions among the public about the "bigness" of Xinjiang.

;

;The air in Xinjiang seems to be filled with baking powder, and food will "expand" several times once it arrives in Xinjiang. For example, 10 kinds of Xinjiang delicacies, including Xinjiang’s No. 1 Nang, Big Plate of Chicken, Noodle Soup for Ten Thousands of People, Largest Oil Cake Tower, and Rice Pilaf for Ten Thousand People, have all set Guinness World Records for their “bigness”. Compared with milk tea that starts at 2 pounds, It can be regarded as a "baby meal".

;

;Xinjiang's largest "Aimai" naan has a diameter of 40 to 50 centimeters. It requires 1 kilogram of flour to make. There are patterns stamped in the middle of the naan, and there are chopped onions or sesame seeds. . Nang with meat in a vat, pitted meat with naan, Xinjiang fried rice noodles with naan... Thousands of ways to eat naan, brewing the nostalgic memory of Xinjiang people when they were children waiting for their mother to break off a piece by the naan pit and feed it to their mouths.

;

;The reason why Xinjiang cuisine is so heavy is that Xinjiang people don’t have the concept of kilograms and liangs. What they call “one kilogram” is actually one kilogram. Because of the "bigness" of Xinjiang, they created their own weights and measures - there are 22 airports in one province of Xinjiang. In their eyes, distances within 1,000 kilometers are very close, and 1,000 kilometers is enough to travel from Beijing to Taiyuan and back.

;

;In addition to the large portions, the prices of Xinjiang dishes are also shocking in Northeast China, which is always known for its affordable prices. According to data from Dianping, the top ten restaurants in Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang, only cost 74 yuan per person, which is lower than the average price in the capitals of the three eastern provinces.

;

;It is large in area and heavy in weight, and the "imagination" of Xinjiang people is also very big. Many Xinjiang people's store names reveal a kind of simple humor. A series of store names such as "Sexy Mommy's Postpartum Recovery Mother and Baby Center" and "Drag and Drive Over" make people laugh.

;

;As an inland province, Xinjiang gives people the impression that it has nothing to do with water. Also because of its "large" territory, Xinjiang has almost all the country's specialties, such as Salmon production accounts for 15% of inland production.

;

;Xinjiang also has great charm. In the first three quarters of this year, Xinjiang received 213.86 million tourists, a year-on-year increase of 77.73%. Tourists rushed to this western land, came with expectations, and left reluctantly as if they were heartbroken. Xinjiang’s specialty paper-skinned walnuts and Hotan jujubes are also on sale on Taobao. Even if they stay at home, they want to taste the taste of Xinjiang.

;

;Today, "know" will talk to you about the "bigness" of Xinjiang.

;September 11, 2023, Zhuozhou, Hebei Province, Wang Haicheng's manuscript of "In That Distant Place". (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/Photo)

;

;A stage play

;

;;Only a few people realize that everything they enjoy at the moment is facing unprecedented challenges. ;

;

;A quarter of an hour before 7:30, outside the West Second Ring Road in Beijing, a group of children and parents gathered in front of the Erqi Theater. It was a cool evening in early September, and the new version of the red children's drama "The Ballad of Soybean" began its national tour here.

;

;Some Chinese people are familiar with this story. In 1940, the Gansu Provincial Working Committee of the Communist Party of China was destroyed. Luo Lili, who was 8 months old, was arrested at the same time as his parents. After several twists and turns, he was imprisoned in Lanzhou Dashagou Prison, where he spent 6 years. Wang Luobin, who was also in prison, asked Luo Lili what the most delicious food in the world was. Luo Lili, who had never been exposed to the outside world, thought it was broad beans that he had eaten by chance. Wang Luobin composed the song "Soybean Ballad" from this.

;

;A while after leaving the venue, the crowd suddenly surrounded an old man.

;

;The old man has appeared on CCTV 13 times. On TV, he is smart, wise, and tall. He is proud that he "didn't make a single mistake" when talking. ", and sometimes, I even have to play and sing "In That Distant Place" on the stage.

;

;But the old man in front of him has droopy eye bags and a lot of white hair on his sparse head. He kept taking out performance tickets from the small shoulder bag on his chest, a total of 40 tickets, which belonged to "old friends" he had met through cooperation in the name of his father.

;

;Most of these "old friends" reached the peak of their careers in the 1990s. They had their own programs in top media and were able to open solo concerts in the most central concert hall in Beijing. Concert, organize a commemorative concert for Wang Luobin in the most famous building.

;

;There are also officials from Zhuozhou, Hebei. This county-level city with a population of 650,000 has a 30-square-meter former residence of Wang Luobin and a Wang Luobin Choir. The director of Zhuozhou Culture and Tourism Bureau and the director of the cultural center drove 60 kilometers to come.

;

;He is the youngest son of Wang Luobin, the "King of Western Singers". Wang Luobin's ancestral home is in Zhuozhou, and a new Wang Luobin Music Memorial Hall is about to be renovated in an old factory in the north of the city as a local cultural landmark.

;

;Wang Luobin, who will appear on the stage in a quarter of an hour, is a "prisoner" who has to go through several political movements before he can be called the King of Singers in the future. , Prison Years, and Social Change.

;

;Wang Luobin's 83-year ups and downs often give playwrights a headache. He once participated in the Northwest Anti-Japanese War Theater Troupe with Xiao Jun, Seke and others. He was also highly appreciated by the warlord Ma Bufang and formed a children's theater troupe in Qinghai. During China's darkest period, he captured a hint of romanticism, and some of the songs he was most proud of in his life were born here, including "In That Distant Place" and "Youth Dance."

;

;At half past seven, "Soybean Ballad" started. I got a chance to film Wang Haicheng, a documentary director who has been following him for more than ten years. The film is called "Looking for Wang Luobin".

;

;For the "old friends" in the audience, some people want to promote this drama to a bigger stage, and some people want to make a movie related to Wang Luobin. , two people respectively proposed to build a music school named after the king of singers in Hebei and Hainan.

;

;They all need to obtain authorization from Wang Haicheng. Only a few people realize that everything the son of the King of Songs enjoys at the moment is facing unprecedented challenges.

;

;;

;

;September 11, 2023 On the same day, in Zhuozhou, Hebei Province, Wang Haicheng displayed his published biography of Wang Luobin and audio-visual products. (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/Photo)

;

;SON OF THE SINGER

;

;;Family has never been a place where the singer is willing to devote his attention;

;

;Wang Haicheng has spent half his life defending his father's honor.

;

;Wang Luobin has two marriages, three sons and several loves. Among the three sons, the eldest went to Australia in the 1980s. The second child was a truck driver and died of illness. After surviving a period of history, the four fathers and sons now only have the third child left. Therefore, interviews, authorizations, rights protection, concerts, commemorations, and publications all fell on Wang Haicheng.

;

;In fact, for a long time, the identity of "Wang Luobin's son" made Wang Haicheng breathless. When he was 8 months old, Wang Luobin was arrested, followed by a search of his home. A month later, his mother passed away in the hospital bed. Relatives in Beijing did not dare to have contact with the Wang family. After hearing about it, the fifth uncle in Zhuozhou drove a carriage all day and night from Beijing in the early winter in the north to bring the body back from Beijing and bury it in a wheat field.

;

;A few years ago, Wang Haicheng tried to find his mother's tomb, but he could no longer find it.

;

;Studying stopped in the second grade of junior high school. When it was time to go to the mountains and countryside, Wang Haicheng stayed on the farm for nine years because of Wang Luobin. When groups of educated young people returned to the city one after another, he also got a nickname: "Cushionzi". This dialect refers to the last puppy out of a litter.

;

;Family is never a place where the singer is willing to devote his attention. Wang Haicheng wrote that the union between his father and his mother was due to the breakup of his father's previous relationship, so he wanted to take revenge on his life. Wang Luobin was born free. He went to the grassland, to the market, and even in prison, collecting folk songs. A producer who visited the singer's deeds mentioned a detail. In his later years, Wang Luobin rode a bicycle everywhere. When it got dark, he would lie on the road and fall asleep, and then go home the next day.

;

;Wang Luobin passed away in 1996. Wang Haicheng immediately joined the China Music Copyright Association and registered 207 musical works recorded, organized and created by Wang Luobin with the association. He became increasingly aware that his father had left a shining legacy. Since 2000, Wang Haicheng has successively published two biographies of Wang Luobin, a song sheet of Wang Luobin, invested in TV films, and a long narrative poem. Four exhibition halls have been created in Turpan, Xinjiang, Haibei, Qinghai, Baishui Ancient Town, Dabancheng, Xinjiang, and Liupan Mountain, Ningxia.

;

;It is difficult to say how father's love plays a subtle role in Wang Haicheng's life. In order to guard this heritage, he was like an ascetic, stationed in the Grape Valley of the Flame Mountain for 16 years.

;

;In the first few years of the 21st century, the Turpan Wang Luobin Music and Art Museum in Grape Valley was the only temple to commemorate the king of singers. This building has an Ottoman-style white circular dome and 80 panels displaying the singer's life. Visitors came in the 40℃ high temperature. When they opened the door, they saw the sweaty son of the singer wearing a shirt with Wang Luobin's logo in front of him. There were biographies, song collections, tapes and records on the counter. When the operation of the art museum was most difficult, Wang Haicheng went to bring in strange stones from the Gobi Desert that looked like pork belly and English letters. This is the most popular commodity in Xinjiang’s tourism market.

;

;He also set up an incense burner in front of his father's portrait - Wang Luobin converted to Buddhism in his later years. There was once a man who claimed to be a physicist and kowtowed three times directly to the portrait.

;

;Wang Haicheng honed his speaking skills, pondered the details of his father's life, paid attention to his image, and never refused any opportunity to appear in the national media. The comment that moved him most came from an old man from Shandong: "Wang Haicheng, you are the biggest filial son in China."

;

;;

;

;On July 24, 2022, Wang Luobin Music Art Museum is located in Grape Valley, Turpan, Xinjiang. (Visual China/Picture)

;

;Salvage and Debate

;

;;Changing one note, two notes, or a chorus counts as "adaptation"? ;

;

;In the 1990s, a modern storm swept through Urumqi: the most cutting-edge local popular music came from further west. Ethnic minorities hold weekly house music gatherings. Seven days and nights after the song "Forgetting Love Water" reached Urumqi, the shops in the Grand Bazaar would use rough-sounding speakers to play versions in other languages. The bars all over the street are full of singing bands. On the radio, the male host can talk endlessly about the Beatles, Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff.

;

;Yibo, the director of "Looking for Wang Luobin", was the popular host of the Urumqi Economic Radio program "Music Leisure Island" at the time. After more than 20 years, she believes that Urumqi at that time showed tolerance for all kinds of music and was the "center of Asian music."

;

;But there is no local singer's name in popular music. His limelight comes from outside Urumqi.

;

;Wang Luobin was rediscovered in the context of an era where order was brought to order. In May 1981, on an afternoon when the temperature suddenly soared to 33°C and the snow suddenly melted, in a five- to six-square-meter concierge at the Qianjin Theater, Xinhua News Agency reporter Zhao Quanzhang met Wang Luobin, who had just been released from prison. In Zhao Quanzhang's reminiscence article, this person who looked like Quasimodo in "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" was unemployed, had no household registration, and did not even have "food and oil connections."

;

;Zhao Quanzhang wrote the internal reference for Wang Luobin, and soon received instructions from Song Renqiong, then head of the Organization Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. Zhao Quanzhang once recalled that the work of bringing order to the country was not completely smooth at that time. The resolution of Wang Luobin's problem had an impact on Xinjiang and the whole country.

;

;Openness was the theme of the 1980s. And for a musician who has experienced the war of resistance, prison, and rehabilitation, is there any symbol more suitable to glimpse a country's path of exploration?

;

;In the autumn of 1988, "Eight Thousand Miles to the Clouds and the Moon" hosted by Taiwanese artist Ling Feng went to Xinjiang to interview Wang Luobin. This was the first program from the other side to introduce China. TV programs about mainland China’s customs and customs. Then, Xia Jie, a female writer from Hong Kong, China, also came to visit and wrote three articles. Soon, Singapore, Australia, North America, and overseas Chinese had someone to pay attention to.

;

;The media calls him the King of Western Singers and enjoys special government subsidies. China Record Corporation awarded him the Golden Record Special Creation Award, and UNESCO awarded him the "Promote "Special Contribution Award for Cultural Exchange between East and West". But all the medals are inferior to the gifts given by the people. In the era when the word "fan" only refers to fans, Wang Luobin's most proud example is, "Chinese friends said that at least half of the two million Chinese in the United States can sing. "In that distant place"".

;

;A more well-known story is that Sanmao, a female writer from Taiwan, China, moved directly into the home of the singer, and scandals abounded.

;

;Trouble is coming quietly. One day in 1993, Luo Dayou's agent called. Not long ago, Rolling Stone Records released the tape "Love Song Anniversary - Luo Dayou and Wang Luobin's Great Collaboration of the Century" without Wang Luobin's consent. The King of Songs was very angry and took Luo Dayou to court for infringement of his copyright.

;

;Greater controversy ensued. Someone revealed that Ling Feng paid 20,000 yuan to buy out ten of Wang Luobin's songs, including "In That Faraway Place", "The Girl from Dabancheng", "Mayila" and "Youth Dance".

;

;The music issue soon turned into a political issue. Someone asked, can Wang Luobin sell folk songs that belong to the people?

;

;A major discussion that lasted for more than a year began. In June 1994, "People's Music" magazine began to discuss the copyright issue of Wang Luobin's folk songs. Dai Penghai, an associate researcher at the Shanghai Conservatory of Music, published two articles criticizing the news media for hyping up Wang Luobin, and also accused Wang Luobin of "selling out the people's sovereignty and interests in national music culture."

;

;There are also people who support Wang Luobin. Liu Zaisheng, a professor at the Music Department of Shandong Normal University, pointed out that “collecting brotherly ethnic songs in different languages ​​is a more complex and difficult task, and the translation and dubbing of lyrics often plays a key role in success or failure.” And “if we combine the When the lyrics are analyzed together, it is not difficult to find that they have formed Wang Luobin's unique creative style that is lyrical, colloquial, and popular."

;

;Another background to the great discussion is that during China's "resumption of customs" negotiations, the Copyright Law was promulgated in 1991, which stipulates that "adaptation, translation, The copyright of works resulting from the annotation and arrangement of existing works shall be enjoyed by the person who adapted, translated, annotated and arranged them." In other words, if Wang Luobin "adapts, translates, annotates, and organizes" folk songs, the copyright of the new songs belongs to him.

;

;But, does changing one note, two notes, or a chorus count as "adaptation"?

;

;On August 5 of that year, a symposium attended by more than thirty people was held in Beijing, including musicologists, composers, and legal professionals. people and journalists. The person presiding over the meeting was Qiao Jianzhong, then director of the Music Research Institute of the China Academy of Arts. He later recalled in an article that this symposium was actually an "absent criticism" against Wang Luobin, which was very explosive. However, the meeting finally reached a consensus that Wang Luobin had worked hard in recording, translating, editing, and adapting folk songs, but the rights he enjoyed needed to be quantitatively analyzed before the rights could be determined.

;

;The eighty-year-old singer was very hurt and left the stage to participate in the debate in person several times.

;

;With the death of Wang Luobin in 1996, the big discussion did not continue. But this discussion could have clarified some fundamental issues, such as the quantitative standards for adaptation and the copyright of folk songs. In that era, Wang Luobin was not the only one who encountered similar problems.

;

;In Shanghai, a young man who was writing "The Complete Works of Xian Xinghai" was also troubled by this problem. In the process of sorting out Xian Xinghai's works, Wu Yuebei, a top student in the composition department of the Shanghai Conservatory of Music, checked and filled in the original scores. Some melodies that he thought were not harmonious even needed to be changed. When Xian Xinghai's descendants heard about Wang Luobin's dispute, they worriedly asked, if the original score was adjusted, would the copyright belong to him?

;

;After consulting the leaders of the Ministry of Culture at the time, "The Complete Works of Xian Xinghai" was finally processed as follows: the works with major changes were also included in the revised original works. version, as well as a more substantial adapted version. For revised or revised editions, the name of the reviser will be marked as a footnote at the end of the work, but no copyright will be generated. The edited version will have a copyright page marked with the name of the organizer, who owns the rights to the content compiled by him in the new version, but not the rights to the original work.

;

;This young man majoring in composition has no way of knowing that after more than 20 years, he may end the discussion about the copyright of the singer.

;

;;

;

;Wang Luobin and Luo Dayou. Reproduced from the photo album saved by Wang Haicheng on September 11, 2023. (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/Photo)

;

;Carpet rights protection

;

;;His opponents include video city vendors, publishing houses, university professors, as well as Li Yuchun, Tan Weiwei and Wang Sulong. ;

;

;The new century is coming, and the law has become a modern weapon to protect rights and interests. Wang Haicheng suddenly discovered that everything his father left behind could be easily taken away.

;

;At that time, China was in the midst of a heat wave to achieve modernization through a market economy. The "resumption of customs" turned into "joining the WTO", a stable and international The integrated legal system is gradually improving. Intellectual property rights are a focus.

;

;In 2002, Wang Luobin's adaptation of "Tall White Poplar" was sued by the family of a deceased musician for copyright infringement. The family members believe that "Tall White Poplar" is not a folk song, but a song composed by the late musician, originally titled "How Beautiful My Garden is."

;

;The family did not sue Wang Haicheng directly, but first sued an audio-visual company in Guangzhou. The CD published by the company labeled "Tall White Poplar" as a folk song. The court found that the song was composed by the late musician. Afterwards, the family took this judgment and sued Wang Haicheng, claiming 230,000 yuan.

;

;Wang Haicheng said that "Tall White Poplar" was written by his father in 1969 while serving a sentence. At that time, a young man was unjustly imprisoned, and his new wife died. The young man stopped cutting his hair and shaving. Wang Luobin felt inspired and adapted "Tall White Poplar" based on an Ili folk song.

;

;A friend in Yili told Wang Haicheng that the original version of this ancient folk song can be found in the local archives. But before he was about to leave, the friend said that the information was missing.

;

;In August 2004, the court of first instance sentenced Wang Haicheng to pay compensation of 237,000 yuan.

;

;After the appeal, Wang Haicheng and his lawyer began to think about how to collect evidence. In October 2005, he and his lawyer pretended to be collectors from Beijing and spent 4,600 yuan to buy a small video camera. After arriving in Yili, they arranged to grab mutton and invited local music teachers and old people who could sing folk songs for interviews. At first, they did not reveal their interest in "Tall White Poplar" and started talking about Ili folk songs. The cameras are always working.

;

;After the conversation was almost over, Wang Haicheng turned to "Tall White Poplar" and asked if there was an original folk song version of this song. Everyone said yes, and everyone hummed a line.

;

;But when they reveal their identities, very few people are willing to testify.

;

;After hitting a wall one after another, they finally found three old people willing to testify. I also met an "Avanti" (meaning "teacher") named Ishamuddin, who said that the original song had probably been circulated for two hundred years, and he also knew that a lawsuit was ongoing.

;

;At that time, Wang Haicheng thought that if he lost the lawsuit, "things would develop like dominoes." Dozens of publishers had published this song Society will also be in crisis. Even if he travels to Hainan, he will pray with Mazu, hoping that Mazu can help him, the son of the king of singers, who is in trouble.

;

;On May 8, 2006, the Xinjiang High Court made a judgment that the two songs each enjoyed property rights in copyright. In Wang Haicheng's words, "Both songs come from folk songs, and they are in a parallel relationship."

;

;At almost the same time, Wang Haicheng launched a blanket rights protection campaign that lasted for several years. For the sake of copyright, he fought against pirated CDs, KTV bosses, and singers who randomly covered his father's works. His opponents include audio-visual city vendors, publishers, university professors, as well as Li Yuchun, Tan Weiwei and Wang Sulong.

;

;It was in 2004 when he was ordered to pay 237,000 yuan in compensation that Wang Haicheng received an unfamiliar phone call. The other party introduced himself like this: Ju Yonghe, a native of Jiangsu, a lawyer in Beijing, and a loyal fan of Wang Luobin.

;

;When they finally met a year later, Wang Haicheng was deeply impressed by his "uprightness and non-joking".

;

;"He said that he was concerned that there were many publications infringing Wang Luobin's rights on the market, and he especially wanted to help protect his rights." Wang Haicheng was "a little nervous financially at the time, and he was also weighing Should I file a lawsuit?" Lawyer Ju dispelled his concerns: He would bear the cost of the lawsuit. If he lost the lawsuit, he would not ask Wang Haicheng for money. If he won, he would pay half of it after deducting travel expenses.

;

;This may be a more subtle way, and it also uses legal weapons to confirm again and again that Wang Luobin owns the copyright to a certain song.

;

;Since 2005, Lawyer Ju has continued to make efforts. He went to the audio and video market and Xinhua Bookstore, walked around, saw the allegedly infringing publications, bought them, issued invoices, and sued. "All those audio and video publishers came to me to ask for authorization. They can also use high-definition pictures of Wang Luobin on the covers of their publications. I also provided the introduction of Wang Luobin on the inside pages. It is more accurate and the text is smoother.";

;Wang Luobin became an inviolable icon. Around 2010, Lawyer Ju moved to KTV. In the words of the time, it was a "mopping up" operation. KTV's infringement made Wang Haicheng even more intolerable. The scenes in "In That Distant Place" were of Hainan beaches and bikini beauties.

;

;Based on the Yangtze River Delta, Lawyer Ju gradually expanded the scope of his operations. In his eyes, "the judicial environment in the Yangtze River Delta was relatively good at the time."

;

;Victory is like a snowball getting bigger and bigger. In the eyes of some people in the music industry, even what didn't belong to him before, now belongs to him.

;

;According to Wang Haicheng, the economic benefits in this round were not as much as people imagined. The compensation involved in the case that he received was "about 120,000 yuan." ". But he is very happy and feels that this battle is going smoothly and "the pirated KTVs have been beaten into silence."

;

;In this battle, he gave himself an indestructible meaning: to maintain his father's eternal status in the history of Chinese music.

;

;But this blanket rights protection came to an abrupt end in 2013, and Wang Haicheng was put in a tight ring. After mediation by the Supreme People's Court, Wang Luobin's descendants reached an agreement: some of the previous lawsuits should be withdrawn. "If the lawsuit cannot be withdrawn, the accepting authority should proactively notify the accepting agency to add Wang Haiyan (eldest brother) and Wang Haixing (second brother) as co-litigants. Everything involving Mr. Wang Luobin's intellectual property rights All litigation actions should be jointly made by three persons (Wang Haiyan, Wang Haixing and Wang Haicheng) to make substantive decisions."

;

;It will be 6 years before Lawyer Ju appears again.

;

;;

;

;2023 On September 10, Wang Haicheng came to an old factory in Zhuozhou, Hebei Province, where the Wang Luobin Music Memorial Hall is being planned. (Southern Weekend reporter Su Youpeng/picture)

;

;Xunge

;

;;On nights like this in the 1970s, Wang Haicheng asked his silent father again and again: I heard that there is a song that is also yours? ;

;

;Wang Luobin left behind a world of lush water and grass, where there were young birds, rivers, long-braided Dabancheng girls, and most of all, It is important to praise the courage of love at all times.

;

;In the world left behind by his father, Wang Haicheng spent more than twenty years marking the birth and origin of each symbol, the youthful bird and the long-braided Da. Bancheng Girl was born in 1938, while Alam Khan did not appear until May 1944.

;

;One ​​reason is that Wang Luobin rarely signs his name. He compiled a book called "Song of the Northwest" related to the Anti-Japanese War. The back cover said "Compiled and printed by the Gansu People's Anti-Enemy Support Association." Wang Luobin said in his autobiography, "I think this work is a citizen's duty." In this special era, many of his songs were not signed.

;

;Wang Hai wrote three biographies of his father, a large part of which is about tracing his father's creative story.

;

;But it was 1974 when he first heard his father talk about his creative motivations. One day, the father and son went to a friend's house to celebrate their child's full moon. With the wine mixed with alcohol, everyone booed and asked Wang Haicheng to sing. He took over the guitar, finished singing "Manli", and vividly talked about the origin of the song.

;

;"There was a pair of lovers on the Mongolian grasslands. During the Anti-Japanese War, the man signed up to join the army to fight. The woman heard from the rear that the man had died. She was very sad and died of illness. "The man came back from the war and heard that his fiancée was dead, so he ran to the cemetery and sang this song in front of her grave. Suddenly, this woman stood up from behind the grave again." Wang Haicheng recalled.

;

;Wang Luobin, who was no longer very talkative, took a sip of wine and said: "Today is so interesting. My son sang a song by Lao Tzu. I didn't know that the song was from Lao Tzu." "Written." It was a pornographic song, and criticism of it reached its peak in the 1950s.

;

;More stories were collected during the period when I temporarily lived with my father at my second brother’s house. Father and son sleep in a small room together, with two beds on the left and right and a window in the middle. During the day, Wang Luobin opened the bed and used the bed board as a table to copy music scores. "He did not forget to revise the songs while copying them, and he sang them while writing." At night, the mosquitoes kept the two awake. On nights like this in the 1970s, Wang Haicheng asked his silent father again and again: I heard that there is a song that is also yours?

;

;But this experience will not be helpful until Wang Haicheng writes his father's biography 30 years later.

;

;After his father passed away, it became more difficult to find songs. The problem of songs was sometimes a legal issue, and sometimes even a political issue. There is only one song whose origin does not need to be searched by Wang Haicheng, and that is "In That Distant Place", the "Crown Pearl" of the King of Western Songs.

;

;In 1939, Wang Luobin followed director Zheng Junli to Qinghai to shoot the movie "Long Live the Nation". Dolma, the daughter of a Tibetan head of thousands of households, was chosen to be the shepherdess. Wang Luobin Become a helper. When catching the sheep, Wang Luobin accidentally pumped a whip on the horse's buttocks, Zhuima on the horse shook the whip and gently hit Wang Luobin's body. So, there was the plot in the lyrics: "I would like to make a lamb/I followed her/I would like to hit me with a leather whip every day."

;

; Mon, 20 Nov 2023 14:25:04 +0800 “4个月挣250元”，去横店当“童漂”值得吗？http://www.infzm.com/contents/260937
;;2023-11-20 12:25:46;
;

;;

;

;According to media reports, many parents are now taking their children to work as "child slaves" in Hengdian, looking for opportunities to star in film and television dramas. The life of "child drifters" is also very bitter. "100 people fight for one seat", "earn 250 yuan in 4 months", and "pay a large amount of money to join the group" are the norm for many "child drifters".

;

;According to media statistics, among the films, online dramas, TV series and other film and television cultural works filmed in Hengdian in 2022, 230 will have underage entertainers participating, with more than 6,000 people participating. This number is not small, and it is also the reason why "child drifting" exists - Hengdian does provide opportunities to act and become famous.

;

;当然，随着各路怀抱梦想的儿童及其家庭的涌入，“童漂”迅速变得内卷。 The "child drifting" industry can no longer be said to be a pure dream-chasing story, but has evolved into a bizarre capital game.

;

;"With 20,000 yuan in 1 year, you are guaranteed to be in at least 3 plays within 1 year, and you can appear as special actors, etc.. With 50,000 in 3 years, you are guaranteed to be in at least 8 plays in 3 years, and you can be in special actors and roles, etc." , this is the charging model of several children's agency companies in Hengdian reported in the media. According to the payment amount, they are divided into various levels of "members" and then equipped with corresponding resources. Obviously, for families who lack economic foundation, "child drifting" is already very cruel, and the return rate is extremely low.

;

;Another problem with "child drifting" is that the main subjects of pursuing dreams are children. If they are in an unstable situation, what about education?

;

;The Compulsory Education Law stipulates that parents or other legal guardians of school-age children and teenagers shall ensure that they enter school on time, accept and complete compulsory education in accordance with the law. If parents let their children leave school early for the dream of being a child star, it is already suspected of breaking the law.

;

;Even if a child successfully completes compulsory education, the basic education is too weak, and the impact may be lifelong. The cost of "child drift" is too huge.

;

;Therefore, parents should have a more rational and comprehensive assessment of the risks of child abuse. After all, there is huge uncertainty in "what you do is what you want". Is it wise for a family to risk everything for an opportunity with a very low probability?

;

;Moreover, children do not yet have full capacity for civil conduct, and they do not actually have a complete and clear understanding of the nature of their own behavior. Many children do like acting, but they lack awareness of "sunk costs" - once their acting career is blocked, how can children return to their regular growth path? Children are ignorant of this, and parents who lack prudence are undoubtedly irresponsible.

;

;Of course, there is no need for public opinion to make excessive criticism of "child drifters" and their families. Some common criticisms on the Internet, such as "using children as money-making tools" and "parents have dreams of getting rich", are not necessarily accurate.

;

;It can be seen from the interviews that many parents just want to try their best to help their children realize their dreams because their children want to act. They are not necessarily profit-driven parents. This is essentially the same as asking their children to "attend a prestigious school". They have both chosen a very involutive path with uncertain prospects.

;

;在规劝家长保持审慎的同时，社会也应当有所干预。 For example, whether those entertainment agencies are formal or not should actually attract the attention of relevant departments. Some parents reported that "bringing money to join the group" was suspected of being defrauded. After paying the money, not only did they have nothing to do, but they were also "blacklisted" by the person involved. For these, the market supervision department should follow relevant clues to investigate whether there are any violations of laws and regulations.

;

;A red line that cannot be blurred is: no matter what growth path a family chooses for their children, education must be compulsorily implemented.

;

;In any case, the bitterness of Hengdian's "child drifting" is, after all, an unspeakable involution. The journey of chasing dreams is of course full of hardships, but this path does not seem to fit in with a simple narrative of children’s growth.

;

;In view of this, parents still need to carefully consider whether "child drifting" is suitable for their family situations; and society should obviously work hard to eliminate the risks and hazards involved, protect the rights of minors, and at least allow them to There are fewer pitfalls on the road to "Tongpiao".

; Mon, 20 Nov 2023 12:25:03 +0800 涉罪的“豆芽”：网售体彩242亿元被控非法经营http://www.infzm.com/contents/260927
;;2023-11-20 11:00:00;
;

;;

;

;On August 3, 2022, Hohhot, passengers took photos on the China Sports Lottery "Lucky Train" themed train. (People’s Vision/Picture)

;

;"The online platform is no longer available?" On November 15, 2023, Wu Yong, the owner of a sports lottery shop in Changxing County, Zhejiang Province, Another inquiry from a regular customer popped up on WeChat. He receives similar messages almost every day.

;

;Wu Yong operates 5 sports betting shops in the county. He was once the owner of the national outstanding sports betting outlets selected by the Sports Lottery Management Center of the State Sports General Administration. But now, he is planning to transfer three of the stores.

;

;On February 16, 2023, Wu Yong was detained by the Public Security Bureau of Jishui County, Jiangxi Province on suspicion of illegal business operations. He was released on bail after "returning the stolen goods" of 1.2 million yuan. Awaiting trial. The Jishui County Procuratorate determined that from 2019 to 2023, Wu Yong sold 127 million yuan in sports betting through the "Douya" App, making illegal profits of more than 8.1 million yuan.

;

;“豆芽”App的运营模式是，彩民线上下单，店主收到通知后，在线下彩票实体店出票。 App operators make money by collecting a 1% handling fee from store owners.

;

;According to the indictment, there are nearly 14,000 lottery agency stores registered in Douya, with more than 2.71 million lottery players. From 2019 to 2023, the total number of lottery tickets sold through "Douzhao" was approximately 24.2 billion yuan.

;

;从时间上看，吴勇等人被指控的行为主要发生在2015年国家对网售彩票清理整顿之后，8年来，财政部没再Open authorization for online lottery sales.

;

;In the criminal law, one condition that constitutes the crime of illegal business is violation of "national regulations." However, the "Lottery Management Regulations" formulated by the State Council in 2009 do not provide for the sale of lottery tickets through the Internet. Relevant regulations are formulated by the Ministry of Finance and other relevant ministries and commissions. During the trial of this case, the focus of dispute between the prosecution and the defense was whether Wu Yong and others violated "national regulations" by selling lottery tickets through the Internet.

;

;;"Ban" brings dividends;

;

;Wu Yong's lottery The store business started ten years ago.

;

;In 2013, the year before the World Cup in Brazil, Wu Yong, a fan, rented a storefront in the business district of Changxing County and ran his first sports betting shop. Open.

;

;At that time, many leading Internet companies launched online lottery sales businesses on their respective platforms, and the business of offline lottery stores was not booming. According to Wu Yong, online lottery sales services have attracted a large number of young people. Before the start of the World Cup, the business of his lottery shop "basically only returned the money", and most of the customers were acquaintances who watched the football with him.

;

;After reviewing relevant public information, the Ministry of Finance has not publicly disclosed the size of the Internet lottery market. One data for reference is the "2014 Internet Lottery Market Analysis Report" released by Pantone Consulting, an organization that has long tracked the lottery market. It shows that in that year, China's Internet lottery sales reached 85 billion, doubling the sales volume in 2013. The market share exceeded 20% for the first time.

;

;However, the hot Internet lottery market was quickly cooled by policies.

;

;On January 15, 2015, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Civil Affairs and the State Sports General Administration jointly issued the "Self-examination and self-correction work on unauthorized use of the Internet to sell lottery tickets" Notice on Problems". At the end of February, several Internet platforms including Alibaba, Tencent, NetEase, Sina, and People's Daily announced they would stop selling lottery tickets.

;

;Unexpectedly and unexpectedly, Wu Yong enjoyed multiple dividends brought by the "ban".

;

;Lottery players who were originally attracted by the Internet platform began to patronize his lottery shop. From time to time, people ask him that buying lottery tickets offline is too troublesome. Is there any way to buy lottery tickets online?

;

;While communicating with colleagues, Wu Yong learned about the application "87 Caidian" (the predecessor of "Douzha"). He found the company's phone number online and called to inquire. Afterwards, the company's sales staff contacted him and asked him to provide store photos, sales certificates, bank cards, ID cards and other qualifications for verification. After passing the approval, Wu Yong's online lottery business started.

;

;After lottery players download the App through the lottery store promotion code shared by Wu Yong, the purchased lottery tickets can only be issued from Wu Yong’s store. Since 2015, online sales have accounted for nearly half of Wu Yong’s total store sales. The subsequent COVID-19 outbreak has further accelerated the development of Wu Yong’s online business. “Almost 70% to 80% of lottery tickets sold through the App will be sold,” he estimated.

;

;2021 is Wu Yong’s best year, with online lottery sales reaching more than 40 million yuan.

;

;Football matches are mostly concentrated in the evening, and lottery players buy tickets half an hour before the game starts. An offline sports lottery store generally only has one terminal ticket issuing machine. When business is booming, the ticket issuing speed cannot keep up. Starting in 2018, Wu Yong successively applied for four sports lottery agency stores as a clerk or relative to absorb more orders.

;

;While using "Bean Sprout", Wu Yong noticed that some store owners were notified by the local sports lottery management center because of their use of this app, and their store sales permissions were suspended. In his store, there are also posters issued by the county sports lottery center prohibiting online lottery sales.

;

;But he "didn't take it seriously." After all, it would be difficult to even recoup the capital by relying on scattered customers in physical stores. “To survive, it is impossible not to use online channels.”

;

;Southern Weekend reporters learned from people close to the case that at least 62 lottery shop owners who have used "bean sprouts" are currently under investigation by the Jishui County Public Security Bureau.

;

;In addition to two shop owners who have been sued to court by the procuratorate, Southern Weekend reporters confirmed with the other six shop owners involved in the case that they were involved in the case between February and June 2023. He was successively released on bail by the Jishui County Public Security Bureau on suspicion of illegal business crimes, and is still under investigation by the public security organs.

;

;These six people expressed similar thoughts to Southern Weekend reporters, "Everyone is doing this. If you don't do it, won't you lose money?" said a shop owner.

;

;;Fluctuating policies;

;

;He and Wu Yong were prosecuted by the Procuratorate There is also another lottery shop owner, as well as Wang Lingfeng, the actual controller of Beijing Chun Xinya Technology Co., Ltd., the operating company of "Bean Sprout", and 6 employees.

;

;Wang Lingfeng entered the Internet lottery industry at the end of 2014. According to what he told Southern Weekend reporters, he entered the industry at the suggestion of the leader of a sports lottery management center in a certain province in East China. Since then, he has been invited by sports lottery centers in many places to provide training to shop owners, "How to use 'Internet +' thinking." Selling lottery tickets'". However, Southern Weekend reporters were unable to verify this with the sports betting agency he mentioned.

;

;In 2016, Wang Lingfeng mentioned in an interview with "Sina Pantone" that before the policy banning the sale of Internet lottery tickets was introduced in early 2015, the company had begun to cooperate with many places. The sports lottery center discussed cooperation. The center recognized their model and was willing to promote it to shop owners. After the ban was issued, all negotiations stopped.

;

;To his surprise, many lottery shop owners took the initiative to find the company. "At that time, I really felt that they were almost finished, but they actually survived."

;

;那次采访中，王岭峰谈到，创业中面临的最大困难，“还是政策”。

;

;The Internet lottery system has experienced a process from tightening to relaxing and then tightening. In China, the only legal lotteries are sports lotteries and welfare lotteries licensed by the State Council. The Ministry of Civil Affairs and the State Sports General Administration are responsible for the management of national welfare lottery and sports lottery respectively, while the Ministry of Finance is responsible for the supervision and management of lottery.

;

;In December 2007, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the State Sports General Administration jointly issued the "Notice on Issues Concerning the Use of the Internet to Sell Lottery Lottery by Lottery Agencies", mentioning We must stop using the Internet to sell lottery tickets.

;

;But in 2010, the Ministry of Finance issued the "Interim Measures for the Administration of Lottery Sales on the Internet" (hereinafter referred to as the "Interim Measures"), pointing out that it is necessary to promptly select companies with Interim Measures Units with specified conditions and good management foundation shall submit to the Ministry of Finance for approval before launching pilot projects.

;

;暂行办法中还强调，未经批准，任何单位不得利用互联网销售彩票。 However, this document is still interpreted by the industry as a positive signal, which means that the online lottery sales model, which was previously in a gray area, is expected to be legalized.

;

;With no organization approved by the Ministry of Finance, the Internet lottery industry has developed rapidly. Portals such as Sina and NetEase and e-commerce platforms such as Taobao, JD.com and Dangdang have all launched lottery services. According to Pantone Consulting statistics, in 2011, China’s Internet lottery sales exceeded the 10 billion yuan mark.

;

;In September 2012, the pilot online lottery sale was launched. The Ministry of Finance agreed with the Sports Lottery Management Center of the State Sports General Administration to entrust China Sports Lottery Network and 500 Lottery Network to carry out online sports betting business.

;

;In 2015, the policy gradually tightened, and relevant departments issued the aforementioned ban on online lottery sales.

;

;On April 28, 2016, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Public Security, the former State Administration for Industry and Commerce, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the State Sports General Administration jointly issued a document pointing out that since 2015, The clean-up and rectification of online lottery sales has achieved initial results, but in some areas there are still problems with orders and prohibitions. The document once again emphasizes that lottery issuance and sales agencies and their agents are strictly prohibited from selling lottery tickets online without authorization.

;

;However, a survey released by CCTV in April 2018 showed that there are still more than 300 lottery websites in operation, with the annual lottery sales amount not less than 1,000 billion. During the start of the World Cup in Russia that year, multiple lottery apps appeared at the top of the download rankings of mobile application malls.

;

;Four months later, on August 21, 2018, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the State Sports General Administration jointly organized 12 ministries and commissions including the National Development and Reform Commission, the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, and the Ministry of Public Security. An announcement was issued to resolutely prohibit unauthorized online lottery sales, and pointed out that the Ministry of Finance has not approved any lottery agency to open this business.

;

;13 days later, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the State Sports General Administration issued another decision on amending the "Implementation Rules of the Lottery Management Regulations", "Unauthorized use of the benefits of Internet sales Lottery and sports lottery" are included in the list of "illegal lotteries".

;

;;

;

;September 3, 2023, Beijing Service Trade Sports Lottery Exhibition in the Sports Services Exhibition Area. (People’s Vision/Picture)

;

;;"National Regulations";

;

;After the policy was tightened in 2015, the Ministry of Finance no longer authorized the sale of lottery tickets on the Internet.

;

;Currently, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the State Sports General Administration can only supervise provincial and municipal lottery distribution centers and agents. Su Guojing, founder of the China Lottery Industry Salon, believes that if online sales of lottery tickets are allowed, once "ticket stealing" and various disputes arise on the online platforms of non-lottery institutions, how and who will supervise them will become a big problem.

;

;The so-called "ticket eating" means that lottery players buy lottery tickets online, but the platform or agent does not actually issue the tickets, but directly pockets the ticket money. If a lottery player wins a small prize, they can cash it in directly. If a lottery player wins a large prize, the platform or the agent cannot pay the fee, and the site may be closed or run away.

;

;"Procuratorial Daily" reported a case of "ticket eating". Sun, the owner of a lottery shop in Shanghai, used the Internet to sell lottery tickets 508 from February to April 2019. Ten thousand yuan, the actual ticket issued was 4.43 million yuan, and the ticket consumption was more than 600,000 yuan. In 2020, the Shanghai Qingpu District Court sentenced Sun to 6 years and 6 months in prison for illegal business operations and fined him 600,000 yuan.

;

;On Douya, every few months, Wu Yong will be asked by customer service to randomly check the actual ticket issuance status. Customer service randomly selects 10 orders. Wu Yong needs to find the corresponding physical tickets, take photos and send them to customer service for review. Wu Yong said that for lottery players’ online orders, he actually issues all tickets offline. The indictment also did not mention his behavior of "eating votes".

;

;However, there will still be "fish that slip through the net" on the platform. A Hunan sports lottery shop owner who was prosecuted by the Jishui County Procuratorate along with Wu Yong was accused of "eating tickets."

;

;According to the indictment, from January 2019 to the end of 2021, he used the "Yuncaidian" App (also the predecessor of "Douzha") to sell 148 million lottery tickets. Yuan, the amount of "ticket eating" was more than 64 million yuan, and the illegal profit was more than 3.27 million yuan. In an interview with Southern Weekend, the shop owner said that he had indeed engaged in the behavior of "eating tickets".

;

;Unlike those who "eat tickets", lottery shop owners such as Wu Yong sell lottery tickets through apps, but issue tickets offline. Are they also suspected of illegal operations?

;

;In January 2022, the Xiushui County Court in Jiangxi Province issued a judgment on a similar case (hereinafter referred to as the "Xiushui Case"). Southern Weekend reporters learned from the defense lawyer of one of the defendants in the case that in this case, neither the lottery app nor the owner of the lottery shop withheld money from the tickets but did not issue them or "eat the tickets".

;

;The Xiushui County Court finally determined that the person in charge of the lottery selling app and several lottery shop owners who cooperated with the app were guilty of illegal business operations.

;

;The basis of the court's decision is that the "Implementation Rules of the Lottery Management Regulations" stipulate that lottery tickets sold on the Internet without authorization belong to the category of illegal lottery tickets. In addition, the App also set up copying and syndicated buying programs with a gambling nature, etc., which changed the rules for lottery sales and prize redemption. "The sales amount was extremely huge and the circumstances were extremely serious, disrupting the order of the lottery market."

;

;Article 225 of the Criminal Law defines the crime of illegal business as violating national regulations, operating specialty items stipulated in laws and regulations without permission, or otherwise disrupting market order. illegal business practices.

;

;After the defendant appealed, the court of second instance upheld the original verdict.

;

;The lawyer in the Xiushui case told Southern Weekend reporters that during the court session, one of the key points in the confrontation between the prosecution and the defense was, what are "national regulations"? As well as the relevant documents prohibiting online lottery sales without approval, are they considered "national regulations"?

;

;On October 9 and 10, 2023, the first instance of the illegal business case involving Wang Lingfeng, Wu Yong and other nine people was held in the Jishui County Court of Jiangxi Province. The above issues were also heard in court. in focus.

;

;Article 96 of the Criminal Law explains "violating state regulations" as violating the laws and decisions formulated by the National People's Congress and its Standing Committee, and the administrative regulations formulated by the State Council. Regulations, prescribed administrative measures, issued decisions and orders.

;

;Wu Yong’s defense lawyer and associate professor at the University of International Business and Economics Zheng Haiping pointed out in court that the "Lottery Management Regulations" were formulated by the State Council and fell into the category of "national regulations." However, the "Regulations" only prohibit the "unauthorized issuance and sale of lottery tickets" and do not explicitly prohibit the use of the Internet to sell lottery tickets.

;

;Prohibitive regulations on the use of the Internet to sell lottery tickets mainly appear in the "Implementation Rules of the Lottery Management Regulations" and the "Interim Measures for the Management of Internet Lottery". However, the former is formulated by the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the State Sports General Administration, while the latter is issued by the Ministry of Finance. From a legal perspective, they are only departmental regulations and shall not be deemed as "violating national regulations."

;

;At present, the Jishui County Court has not made a first-instance judgment.

;

;;The distribution pattern may be broken;

;

;"Bean Sprout Case" The other six shop owners who have not yet been charged are also waiting for the verdict. They opened offline lottery shops in Fujian, Shandong, Jiangsu and other places. They all claimed that they did not "eat tickets". After paying "illegal gains" ranging from hundreds of thousands to millions, they were released on bail pending trial.

;

;代理了修水县法院审理的非法经营案后，前述代理修水案的律师又陆续接到了近十件类似案件当事人的咨询， "More than 80% of cases are filed and investigated by the public security organs of Jiangxi Province." This means that lottery shop owners who use online sales are facing the risk of criminal offenses.

;

;Despite the risks, it is not uncommon for stores to sell lottery tickets through online channels.

;

;On November 13, 2023, Southern Weekend reporters randomly called 10 sports lottery stores in Beijing and asked as lottery players whether they could buy lottery tickets online. Eight lottery stores stated that they can add WeChat and purchase online, and two of them sent App download links for online sports lottery purchases.

;

;As far as the attitude of the regulatory authorities is concerned, the characterization of purchasing lottery tickets through the App is different from that of letting store owners purchase lottery tickets through WeChat.

;

;Southern Weekend reporters learned from the sports lottery management centers in Beijing, Zhejiang, Hunan and other places that purchasing lottery tickets through Apps is explicitly prohibited, but purchasing lottery tickets by adding the store owner’s WeChat account Whether it is a violation or not has not yet been clearly defined.

;

;The Huzhou Sports Lottery Center in Zhejiang Province, where Wu Yong is located, believes that buying lottery tickets on WeChat is an online lottery behavior and "is not as serious as illegal, but we do not advocate it." The Changsha Sports Lottery Center stated that if any lottery shop owners are found to be selling lottery tickets through WeChat channels, they “may be punished by withdrawing their tickets.”

;

;Why is it so difficult for online lottery sales to be loosened? Su Guojing told Southern Weekend reporters that in China, the public welfare nature of lottery is emphasized while its gambling attribute is weakened. Internet platforms provide more convenient sales channels and payment methods than offline purchases, but they may cause lottery players to become addicted and make it more difficult to control minors’ lottery purchases.

;

;Chen Haiping, associate professor at the School of Psychology at Beijing Normal University and former deputy director of the China Lottery Research Center, said that another problem caused by Internet lottery sales is that the original The distribution pattern of public welfare funds has been broken.

;

;Lottery funds are divided into three parts: bonuses, issuance fees and public welfare funds. According to regulations of the Ministry of Finance, half of the lottery public welfare funds in each province are turned over to the central finance, and the other half is retained in the provincial finance. The Internet sales of lottery tickets break geographical restrictions. In provinces with developed Internet economies, sales will increase and more public welfare funds will be retained in local finances. Provinces dominated by offline sales will inevitably lead to a decrease in public welfare funds. This can easily lead to unhealthy competition in lottery sales among provinces, which will not only break the original pattern of raising and distributing public welfare funds and create new inequality between rich and poor, but also lead to various market chaos.

;

;In Su Guojing's view, if the lottery industry does not introduce higher-level laws and "if the responsibilities and rights in Internet sales are not clarified, the problem cannot be completely solved." ".
